Award.AwardTitle: Core Support for the Geographical Sciences Committee at the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides continued core support for the Geographical Sciences Committee (GSC) of the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine. Continued support for the GSC will enable this committee to bring academics, private sector and government researchers, and policy makers together through roundtables and studies to reach consensus on the most challenging and significant issues in the geographical sciences. The GSC will continue to provide a forum through which geographers and researchers in related fields may conduct assessments of the current state of the science and explore future research opportunities. The GSC will serve a critical intermediary role by facilitating interactions between government agencies and researchers in academic, nonprofit, and private sector settings, thereby facilitating capabilities for a broad range of researchers and organizations to engage in constructive dialogue at the interface of geographical science and policy at the national level. The committee also will advance the role that geographers and related scientists play internationally through its role as the U.S. national committee for the International Geographical Union.

The National Academies established a Geographical Sciences Committee in 1997 to bring the theories and perspectives of the geographical sciences to bear on society's problems. The GSC has provided advice to the National Academies on all matters pertaining to geography. The GSC has fostered international cooperation by serving as a liaison to other national geographical organizations and by initiating collaborative research programs among those organizations, and it has served as the official U.S. liaison to the International Geographical Union (IGU), promoting and facilitating participation of U.S. geographers in the IGU. The GSC undertakes its work through the conduct of special studies and through its meetings. The GSC will identify topics for further study that enable the geographical sciences community to address problems of societal significance. The GSC also will conduct an enhanced range of outreach activities, such as webinars and workshops focusing on topics like the use of geographic information systems to make urban mobility more sustainable and long-term approaches for wildland fire management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Geographical Sciences Committee (GSC) of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine has as a principal intellectual focus the identification of place-based vulnerabilities and geographers' contributions to ensuring an understanding of these vulnerabilities and the security and well-being of people. Through its ability to bring together geographers and practitioners in relevant fields to exchange ideas and knowledge on topics related to place-based vulnerabilities, the committee is proactive in employing various mechanisms to communicate information with its sponsors, other government agencies and entities, and private, professional, non-governmental, and academic organizations. During the reporting period, the committee collaborated with the National Academies Mapping Sciences Committee to host a public meeting titled "The Federal Landscape of Geographical and Mapping Science," which gathered 45 people in person and 8 online from across the federal sector, academia, and industry to discuss and examine "Analyzing and Communicating Flood Risk", "Mapping the New Arctic", and "Smart Technologies and Communities" through a series of keynote speakers and panelists. The discussions throughout the meeting day helped to foster communication and collaboration across sectors within and around the geographical and mapping sciences, with the aim of helping to identify new areas for research in the geographical sciences and helping support the provision of accurate and timely input for science- and engineering-based decision making in the nation. The topic of smart technologies and communities seemed particularly ripe for further investigation, generating the most dialogue among the meeting participants. The committee may focus more intently on this topic in the next year, including how automation will affect the transportation of goods and those employed by the transportation industry. In conjunction with this joint meeting of the two committees, the GSC also hosted the annual Gilbert F. White Lecture in Geographical Sciences on the topic "Synergy Between Geography and Mapping with the Nation?s Energy Mission." The lecture by Dr. Budhendra Bhaduri sought to identify the critical role that geography and mapping research play in supporting the energy resources and systems that underlie all aspects of U.S. society, security, and economy.
